bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 186 (Friday, October 30, 2020)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. HUDSON:H.R. 14.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8[Page H5715]

item.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Department of Health and Human Services
Drug safety, medical device, and laboratory regulation
Emergency medical services and trauma care
Government ethics and transparency, public corruption
Social work, volunteer service, charitable organizations

summary.text:
Commitment to Defeat the Virus and Keep America Healthy Act

This bill provides funding for various public health programs and activities and revises multiple provisions, including within the tax code, to respond to COVID-19 (i.e., coronavirus disease 2019) and otherwise address health outcomes.

The bill specifically makes changes to support pharmaceutical manufacturing and supply chains; prevent diversion of controlled substances; increase access to telehealth services under Medicare; and expand various public health programs to address health disparities, maternal and infant health, and behavioral health.

bill.title: Commitment to Defeat the Virus and Keep America Healthy Act

item.title: Commitment to Defeat the Virus and Keep America Healthy Act
To increase the Federal commitment to defeating the virus that causes COVID-19 and prepare for future pandemics, and for other purposes.
Commitment to Defeat the Virus and Keep America Healthy Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Railroads, Pipelines, and Hazardous Materials.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
